awd_titl_txt: Conference: The 17th US-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology: Next-Generation Semiconductors and the Environmental Implications of Semiconductor Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
The Forum on Nanotechnology between the U.S. and Korea has been held annually since 2003 in alternating countries, except during the COVID-19 pandemic. These forums focus on enhancing research collaboration in the field of nanotechnology among scientists and engineers from both countries. The joint forum facilitates networking between the research communities and agencies of both countries, promoting exchange of information and new opportunities for research collaboration. The forum’s topics this year will be Next-Generation Semiconductors and the Environmental Implications of Semiconductor Manufacturing. One keynote speaker, seven senior presenters and seven early-career presenters from the U.S. will participate with the same number of Korean presenters. The organizing committee will emphasize diversity of the participants. This forum will bring together a bi-national community of expert researchers and innovators who are working at the leading edge of next-generation semiconductors and environmentally benign semiconductor manufacturing. The outcome of this forum will lead to milestones and vigorous research collaboration between the U.S. and Korea in semiconductor technology that can generate significant economic and social impact. The forum’s proceedings and findings will be made available to a broad audience on Carnegie Mellon’s website.

Semiconductor technology will be an important thrust area in economic development, defense, and security for the U.S. and Korea over the next decade. This forum will explore cost/performance gains using 3D integration through monolithic and heterogenous integration and advanced packing processes to continue Moore’s law.  Further decreases in chip sizes will require novel environment, health, and safety (EHS) solutions. Therefore, development of novel devices that use nanotechnology to evaluate semiconductor fabrication chemistry for toxicity, environmental fate, and behavioral characteristics will be discussed. Cost effective methods that use nanotechnology with a multiscale approach are needed to assure that wastewater effluents and air emissions have minimal environmental impact.  Ultra-pure water (UPW) is important in semiconductor manufacturing and fabrication processes. Thus, novel reduction, reuse, and recycling techniques for UPW in manufacturing and chemical mechanical planarization in conjunction with EHS will also be discussed. The broader impacts will include new recommended paradigms in semiconductor science, environmentally benign manufacturing, and education, as well as new collaborations in the semiconductor manufacturing research, especially among early-career scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Semiconductors are essential to our modern lives. Without them, our mobile phones, laptops and cars could not function. They have enabled technological advances from the human genome project to advances in telecommunication and mobile computers. The presidents of both the U.S. and Korea promised an alliance between their countries as the semiconductor industries become critical to their countries’ security and economic development. Since 2003, the Forum on Nanotechnology between the U.S. and Korea has been held annually in alternating countries, except during the COVID-19 pandemic years. During these two decades, the forums have focused on enhancing research collaboration among scientists and engineers from both countries in the field of nanotechnology. Specifically, this joint forum facilitates networking between the research communities and agencies of both countries, enabling each side to exchange information and to explore opportunities for research collaboration. In this forum, we have fostered a common platform for scientists and engineers from both countries to develop and accommodate emerging technology where nano/semiconductor technology provides critical solutions. This year’s forum was focused on “Next-Generation Semiconductors and the Environmental Implications of Semiconductor Manufacturing.” Three keynote speakers, ten senior presenters, and four early-career presenters from the U.S. were invited. Sixty-seven eminent scientists and policy makers in the field of nanotechnology/semiconductor technology also attended. Our forum has also served as a benchmark for other international technology forums. This Forum provided a gateway for opening a new paradigm in semiconductor technology for the future as the U.S. and Korea have been heavily supporting semiconductor technology as a prioritized economic development area.

During this forum, participants discussed the development of advanced semiconductor devices including the topics of advanced packaging and heterogeneous integration as well as various strategies and advancements to address the environmental impact of semiconductor manufacturing. Focus was directed to per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) remediation, alternative materials, sustainable processes, and international collaboration to reduce the industries’ carbon footprint and promote sustainability. Semiconductor production significantly impacts the environment, requiring vast energy and water resources, generating hazardous waste, and using concerning materials such as PFAS.

The format of this forum consists of oral presentations, poster presentations, and virtual presentations using Zoom, as well as subgroup discussions to generate recommendations on the sustainability of future semiconductor manufacturing in both countries. These discussions will enable the U.S. to pivot towards transformative approaches for novel semiconductor design and fabrication. In addition, some participants visited a Korean government lab, a university, and industry sites and a group visited the Korean National NANOFAB Center.

We could not hold the Forums during the past three years due to the COVID-19 pandemic. At that time, we planned a virtual Forum using Zoom. Adopting this idea, we made the format of this Forum to be a hybrid one by combining a traditional meeting (in-person) with virtual presentations (online). This forum was the first combined online U.S.-Korea nanotechnology forum.

In addition to the Forum recommendations, our Forum discussed obtaining NSF(US) and NRF(Korea) grants for collaboration via meetings between Korea ministry / NSF personnel. International collaborative research outcomes may be delayed due to challenges in finding mutual benefits, legislative procedures, and sparse funding sources. Since the 1st U.S.-Korea Nanotechnology Forum, we have witnessed numerous collaborations between the two countries arising from our Forums. During the past seven years, the forum participants have created and sustained collaboration teams on specific topics relevant to Korea and the U.S. These teams applied for NSF grants for joint research, and we strongly recommended international collaboration programs between two countries.

All forum proceedings and findings are available on Carnegie Mellon’s website for a broad audience.

 

Intellectual Merits

The novel contribution of this forum was its ability to bring together a bi-national community of expert researchers and innovators who are working on the leading edge of next-generation semiconductors, including advanced packaging and heterogenous integrations, as well as environmental, health, and safety issues in semiconductor manufacturing. This forum stimulated efforts to promote these areas by fully utilizing nanotechnology convergence to semiconductor and environmental technologies. The outcome of this forum led to tangible milestones and vigorous research collaboration for both countries where semiconductor technology significantly impacts national security and economic development.

 

Broader Impacts

Along with the exchange of ideas among the leading scientists and engineers in the nano/semiconductor technology area, this forum recommended new paradigms for future semiconductor science and environmentally benign manufacturing. This forum contributed to security, the global environment, and economic development in a broader sense via discussions on novel semiconductor technology and sustainability in manufacturing. This forum promoted the funding opportunities and research collaboration between the two countries, especially for young scientists.
